note that by LC we don't have to have commitements to implement, only agreement that the features should be in the language
Hixie: it's the "isn't a priority" to browser developers that's the big stumbling block
in fact it's only when entering CR that we have to list features that might be at risk
and even then we have until REC to see them implemented
so lack of implementation commitements is not a big deal so long as implementors don't disagree that it would be good to implement eventually
commitments

myvidoop.com no longer shows an EV cert. Am I being MITMed?
e.g., threat "this is going to be removed from HTML5 unless we get a clear indication of vendor support"
hsivonen: MITMed
MikeSmith: Man In The Middle
watches the EV cert security model fall apart
hsivonen: do what normal people do and discard any dialogs and don't notice the lack of dialogs
EV cert, despite whatever faults it has, is approximately one gazillion times better than non-EV certs
for cert vendors, sure
MikeSmith: how so. It's causing me distress now. Probably for no good reason.
If I'm being MITMed, how do I email vidoop, when I should assume that by now the MX record in my DNS cache is poisoned as well?

certs in general can answer the question "is this who i think it is", which is never a question users ask. They ask (implicitly) the question "am I being attacked", which is not possible to answer using any kind of SSL cert that I know of, EV or otherwise.
(and EV certs can answer the first question with $450 more confidence than non-EV certs, that's about it.)
Hixie: EV certs have documented rules for identity
right. "$450 more confidence".
when you pay (whatever dollar amount) for a non-EV cert, you are a sucker
because you are paying for nothing
you are paying for someone to sign it
CAs are bound to do zero vetting otherwise
You're paying for something that prevents passive network attackers from reading all the data send to/from your web site, which seems quite useful
*sent
Philip`: you can get that with a self-signed cert
Hixie: You can't since it won't work in Firefox 3

the EV-cert work is similar to a lot of things in that it's really easy to make jackass comments about it from the outside after the fact, throwing rocks, without any understanding of the difficulties involved in ever having tried to do something like it all
Philip`: that's a bug (it should encrypt but not show any ui about it)

Has Philip` inadvertently found yet another browser security bug

right - due to an invalid kern table in one of the subsetted fonts
you're cc'd

we could potentially do some more validation, but it's not feasible to exhaustively test fonts before handing them over to the OS or font rendering library, so if that isn't completely robust, bad fonts will always be a risk
wonders why his copy of the font doesn't look anything like a font, and then realises after several minutes that it's been gzipped
looking at the original PixAntiqua.ttf, i see that it has the apple-format kern table, and offhand it looks valid
i guess the subsetting code is at fault, then, when it strips out all the irrelevant kern pairs from the subset font
ah, looks like the problem is Kern.pm (from Font::TTF).... it always packs the kern table header in the old format, without checking the version number to see whether that's correct
was coming to the same conclusion :-)
Is kern table version 1 documented somewhere?
http://developer.apple.com/textfonts/TTRefMan/RM06/Chap6kern.html
notes there seems very little point in the bug being marked security sensitive now since most of the information needed to reproduce it seems to be documented here :)
I suppose I'd really have to support it properly, to fix up all the glyph IDs, and can't just pass it through :-(
but I'm too lazy to do that
but I could make it just drop the entire kern table
